awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Powering Micro Scale Biomedical Implants through Controlled Low Frequency Magnetic Fields and Multiferroic Transducers
awd_abstract_narration:
Biomedical implants hold the promise of dramatically improving health and well-being by, for example, enabling people to pro-actively monitor health through real-time tracking of internal body chemistry (e.g. pH, glucose, lactate, tissue oxygen), treat diseases through targeted and tailored drug delivery, treat neural disorders through neural prostheses, etc. However, this vision is only possible if implants become much smaller with longer lifetimes.  The current state of the art in integrated circuit and micro-sensor design and manufacturing could enable cubic millimeter sized implants that would greatly reduce trauma to the patient and improve continuous health monitoring. However, power systems have lagged behind and become a barrier to implant miniaturization. Very small batteries would quickly become depleted and then the entire implant would have to be surgically replaced. The goal of this project is to overcome this power problem by wirelessly transmitting power to the biomedical implants using low frequency magnetic fields that easily penetrate the human body. These magnetic fields will excite a magnetoelectric power receiver that will be part of the implant.  The magnetoelectric receiver will convert the magnetic fields to electricity which will then be properly conditioned to power the implant.  The Principle Investigator (PI) and affiliated researchers will explore two competing types of magnetoelectric devices and characterize them especially in terms of uncertainties related to the position and alignment of the implant and associated power receiver.  New fabrication processes will be developed that enable micro-scale magnetoelectric devices to generate more power, thus enabling further miniaturization for biomedical implants.  In addition to enabling the miniaturization of implants, the work to be accomplished by this project could have broader benefits for the state of the art in both sensing and wireless power transfer.

The goal of this project is to explore the use of low frequency magnetic fields coupled with magnetoelectric power receivers to transmit power to biomedical implants. The target goal is to safely supply 100 microwatts per cubic millimeter, which would enable a wide range of implanted sensors and therapeutic devices.  Low frequency magnetic fields are attractive because of their very low absorption in human tissue and encapsulating structures. Two classes of magnetoelectric devices will be investigated: laminates of magnetostrictive and piezoelectric material, and jointly fabricated permanent magnet / piezoelectric structures. The two approaches will be compared given alignment and orientation uncertainties and issues associated with human tissue interaction. Specifically, researchers will characterize the surrounding tissue's role in degrading the quality factor of the resonant magnetoelectric power receivers.  The key relationships for power generation by this method as well as performance limits will be elucidated and experimentally validated, which will serve as a basis for system design. A new microfabrication process will be developed to enable high power transducers through the use of much thicker active materials (i.e. piezoelectric and magnetostrictive). Finally, a system to control the DC voltage used by the implant from the external transmitter will be developed and validated to remove the need for large onboard passive components associated with traditional power electronics. The efficacy of the external control method will be fully characterized with respect to stability of the DC voltage and robustness to system uncertainties. The results of this research will establish the basis for much smaller, more ubiquitous biomedical implants by overcoming the issue of delivering power at sufficient densities.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Extremely small, minimally traumatic biomedical implants could enable people to manage their health more proactively and treat disease more effectively. Advances in microelectronics and sensing technologies can currently enable extremely small (< cubic millimeter), biomedical implants.  However, systems of this size are almost never actually realized because the powering system, usually a battery, is too large. Therefore, the goal of this project was to explore wireless power transfer technology that would enable the powering of very small biomedical implants. Most wireless power transfer systems transmit power from one coil (a transmitter) to another coil (a receiver). In the case of biomedical implants, the receiver would be implanted inside the human body. For such systems to operate efficiently, the receiver coil would typically have to be too large for millimeter-scale implants. Therefore, we investigated and developed a wireless power transfer system based on a novel receiver technology, magnetoelectric (ME) composites. Like a receiving coil, ME composites convert oscillating magnetic fields to an electrical signal that can be used to power the implant. However, unlike a receiving coil, the magnetic field causes the ME composite to mechanically vibrate, and these vibrations are then converted to electricity. Because the mechanical vibration wavelength, which defines the size of the ME composite, is much shorter than the electromagnetic wavelength, which defines the size of a coil-based receiver, the ME composites can operate efficiently at much smaller sizes. Our target was to be able to generate 100 microwatts of power in a volume of one cubic centimeter, which would enable a wide range of implants. We explored the fundamental physics of different types of ME composites, developed mathematical models to predict the transferable power while staying below safety restrictions, and developed a full wireless power transfer system based on ME composites. Our models indicate that our target power density is possible. With our current system we can transfer over 1000 microwatts of power to a device that is a few millimeters on a side. Furthermore, we have developed and demonstrated all the necessary technologies to enable mm-scale wireless power transfer based on ME composites.

 

Intellectual Merit

As part of this project, we created and experimentally validated mathematical models for different types of ME composite architectures. These models enable prediction of transferable power output taking safety, power, and size constraints into consideration. They also provide a tool to create optimal designs. Using these models, we demonstrated that a particular architecture, a longitudinal mode oscillator consisting of layers of magnetostrictive and piezoelectric materials, was the most promising of the architectures evaluated. Our models further indicate that safe power densities of over 250 microwatts per cubic millimeter at the location of the implant are achievable. One of the challenges of ME composite receivers is that they operate most efficiently in the presence of a large static magnet field. This can be created by placing permanent magnets near the ME receiver. However, such a configuration does not work for biomedical implants. Therefore, we explored a technique called magnetization grading to create ME composite receivers, which we call zero-bias devices, that do not need any static magnetic field bias. We developed predictive models for such devices and produced receiver structures that were able to produce over 1000 microwatts of power in a device of 10 X 1 X 3.8 millimeters in size. Finally, we developed and demonstrated a full wireless power transfer system using an external coil transmitter and a ME composite receiver to power a wireless sensor. As the location and orientation of the receiver would not be exactly known, the transmit coil automatically orients itself, using a feedback signal from the receiver, to maximize the power transfer to the receiver all the while ensuring that transmitted power stays below safe levels.

 

Broader Impacts

Biomedical implants hold the promise of dramatically improving our health and well-being by, for example, enabling us to pro-actively monitor health through real-time tracking of internal body chemistry (e.g., pH, glucose, lactate, tissue oxygen), treat diseases through targeted and tailored drug delivery, treat neural disorders through neural prostheses, etc.  However, this vision is only possible if implants become much smaller and power sources with sufficient power density can be developed.  This work sought to overcome this power barrier.

In addition to the societal impact resulting from the scientific and technological advancements, we provided training and career development for many people through this project. Research conducted on this project helped train five graduate students. An additional five undergraduate students conducted research as part of this project. The graduate students and lead researcher created hands-on learning modules for summer camps for high school aged young women interested in engineering. Finally, nine high school students contributed to the research on this project through summer internships.

 


Last Modified: 04/22/2023
Modified by: Shad Roundy
